Interesting point. One that we have been kicking around here in the 
office this week as well. We have been using the term "syntactically 
correct" to indicate a document that would pass some kind of XML 
validation. However this does not mean the document makes sense in a 
browser - perhaps there are CSS mistakes or JavaScript mistakes, or 
basic HTML mistakes. If a document does make sense in a browser, we have 
been calling it "semantically correct".

These are probably not the best use of the terms "syntax" and 
"semantics" but it seems to convey the intended difference.

Automating the process of testing if a page is syntactically correct 
seems to be reasonably easy through the use of an XML parser.

The semantic checking is a much more interesting problem. Validating 
CSS, or JavaScript is probably doable. But in my experience the biggest 
problem in testing a web application is the variety of browsers and OSs 
that are out there and attempting to cover even a small set of these in 
QA is resource intensive. Small differences in rendering that need to be 
tweaked with custom CSS, or certain tags that a browser docent support, 
or keywords that mean something in one browser and not another.

Anyone have any tools they use for this task? Are there any tools? Is it 
even reasonable to think that automation for this type of testing is 
possible?


J. B. Rainsberger wrote on 9/9/2004, 11:32 AM:

 > Craig Dickson wrote:
 >
 > > Do you want to validate that the .jsp file is a valid JSP document, or
 > > do you want to validate that the output of the .jsp file (probably HTML
 > > etc.) is valid? Both options are valid, but are definitely not the same
 > > thing.
 > >
 > > My original question that started this thread was more aimed at the
 > > second option (validating the output of the JSP, not the contents of
 > the
 > > .jsp file itself).
 >
 > OK. How do you define a valid HTML document? Different browsers do that
 > differently. Do you mean something that conforms to a given DTD? XML
 > schema? If so, then simply instantiate an XML parser with validation
 > enabled, parse(), then either see an exception (invalid) or don't
 > (valid). XMLUnit does this out of the box.
 >
 > <snip />
 > > Then you could
 > > use the previously mentioned validating XML parser to validate your
 > JSPs.

 > Certainly, if you can write your JSPs to themselves be XML documents,
 > then you can forget that they are JSPs and just treat them as XML
 > documents! :) It's a Good Thing.
